articles.headline: Legislators Recall Governor Who Didn’t Mingle
articles.snippet: For Massachusetts officials used to the glad-handing of local politics, Mitt Romney was an unfamiliar breed. His approach could offer hints of how a possible President Romney might deal with Congress.
articles.abstract: For Massachusetts officials used to the glad-handing of local politics, Mitt Romney was an unfamiliar breed. His approach could offer hints of how a possible President Romney might deal with Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Well into Mitt Romney’s tenure as governor of Massachusetts, a state legislator named Jay Kaufman developed a nagging suspicion: the governor had no idea who he was.

articles.headline: Retailers Add Gadgets for Shoppers at Ease With Technology
articles.snippet: Retailers like Macy’s and Nordstrom are accommodating younger consumers who prefer using technology to research products instead of asking employees.
articles.abstract: Retailers like Macy’s and Nordstrom are accommodating younger consumers who prefer using technology to research products instead of asking employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Nadia Karim goes shopping, she doesn’t wait around for salespeople. She saves items from apps and Web sites on her cellphone as a shopping list. And as she browses one store — recently trying on Sam Edelman flats at Nordstrom — she uses the phone to check out styles at competitors like Macy’s.

articles.headline: The Web Is Awash in Reviews, but Not for Doctors. Here’s Why.
articles.snippet: Many patients fear tangling with a litigious doctor, or being blackballed by the profession after a negative review of one of its members.
articles.abstract: Many patients fear tangling with a litigious doctor, or being blackballed by the profession after a negative review of one of its members.
articles.lead_paragraph: For all the debate about which Web sites have the best model for reliable reviews — paid or unpaid, anonymous or real name, Angie’s List or Yelp or TripAdvisor — one thing is certain: a robust ecosystem exists online for restaurant and hotel reviews that has changed those industries for the better.

articles.headline: When Debating the Auto Bailout, Consider Lehman’s Fate
articles.snippet: As Republican candidates denounce the federal bailout of General Motors and Chrysler, it’s useful to remember what happened when Lehman Brothers was denied government help.
articles.abstract: As Republican candidates denounce the federal bailout of General Motors and Chrysler, it’s useful to remember what happened when Lehman Brothers was denied government help.
articles.lead_paragraph: Would Americans be better off if General Motors and Chrysler had simply gone bankrupt, without benefit of taxpayer assistance?

articles.headline: Discreetly Digital, Erotic Novel Sets American Women Abuzz
articles.snippet: The book, “Fifty Shades of Grey,” by an obscure author, E L James, has been described as “Mommy porn” and “Twilight” for grown-ups.
articles.abstract: The book, “Fifty Shades of Grey,” by an obscure author, E L James, has been described as “Mommy porn” and “Twilight” for grown-ups.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Fifty Shades of Grey,” an erotic novel by an obscure author that has been described as “Mommy porn” and “Twilight” for grown-ups, has electrified women across the country, who have spread the word like gospel on Facebook pages, at school functions and in spin classes. Or as the handwritten tag on a paperback copy in a Montclair, N.J., bookstore helpfully noted, “Yes, this is THE book everyone is talking about.”

articles.headline: German Leader and I.M.F. Chief Split Over Debt
articles.snippet: Despite their friendship, Angela Merkel and Christine Lagarde face difficult discussions over how to handle a future crisis, with opposing stances on the amount of money needed to protect vulnerable economies and how it should be raised.
articles.abstract: Despite their friendship, Angela Merkel and Christine Lagarde face difficult discussions over how to handle a future crisis, with opposing stances on the amount of money needed to protect vulnerable economies and how it should be raised.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — With a deal on Greek debt finally done, Europe will shift its attention to two of its most powerful women, friends who have dueling views about what needs to be done to prevent future Greek-like meltdowns from spreading to other economies.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Kulish and Annie Lowrey

articles.headline: India Eyes Muslims Left Behind by Quota System
articles.snippet: The issue of affirmative action for Muslims surfaced in an election in Uttar Pradesh, with promises to Muslims of quotas like those for low-caste Hindus.
articles.abstract: The issue of affirmative action for Muslims surfaced in an election in Uttar Pradesh, with promises to Muslims of quotas like those for low-caste Hindus.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUZAFFARNAGAR, India — Along the narrow lane known as Khadar Wallah, Muslims and low-caste Hindus have lived side by side for years, bound by poverty, if not religion. Yet recently, Muslims like Murtaza Mansuri have noticed a change. Their neighbors have become better off.

articles.headline: Beyond Mile-High Grub: Can Airline Food Be Tasty?
articles.snippet: Carriers are turning to science and celebrity chefs to figure out how to make onboard meals more appealing to high-revenue business travelers.
articles.abstract: Carriers are turning to science and celebrity chefs to figure out how to make onboard meals more appealing to high-revenue business travelers.
articles.lead_paragraph: ONE of the world’s busiest airports, Hartsfield-Jackson in Atlanta, lies a mere 1,026 feet above sea level. Which, it turns out, is perfect for your taste buds.

articles.headline: Hits, and Misses, in a War on Bribery
articles.snippet: The Justice Department is waging an aggressive — and controversial — campaign against bribery in global business.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department is waging an aggressive — and controversial — campaign against bribery in global business.
articles.lead_paragraph: PRISON is the last place Albert J. Stanley seemed destined for. But on Feb. 23, Mr. Stanley, a legendary figure in the high-octane world of Big Oil, was sentenced to two and a half years for his role in one of the biggest bribery cases in American history.

articles.headline: Revisiting a $400 Million Tax Break
articles.snippet: Fairfax Financial Holdings was able to reduce its taxes by $400 million, but a question has dogged the deal that allowed it to do so.
articles.abstract: Fairfax Financial Holdings was able to reduce its taxes by $400 million, but a question has dogged the deal that allowed it to do so.
articles.lead_paragraph: IF you saw $20 on the ground, would you stop to pick it up? Silly question.

articles.headline: Prisons Rethink Isolation, Saving Money, Lives and Sanity
articles.snippet: A growing number of states are rethinking the use of long-term isolation and re-evaluating how many inmates require the punishment that’s been long opposed by humanitarian groups.
articles.abstract: A growing number of states are rethinking the use of long-term isolation and re-evaluating how many inmates require the punishment that’s been long opposed by humanitarian groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARCHMAN, Miss. — The heat was suffocating, and the inmates locked alone in cells in Unit 32, the state’s super-maximum-security prison, wiped away sweat as they lay on concrete slab beds.

articles.headline: Obama Plans Big Effort to Build Support Among Women
articles.snippet: President Obama’s campaign will use the debate over the new health care law to amplify an appeal that seems to be benefiting from clashes on birth control and abortion.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s campaign will use the debate over the new health care law to amplify an appeal that seems to be benefiting from clashes on birth control and abortion.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s re-election campaign is beginning an intensified effort this week to build support among women, using the debate over the new health care law to amplify an appeal that already appears to be benefiting from partisan clashes over birth control and abortion.

articles.headline: Security Fears Lead Groups to Rethink Work in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: Anti-American unrest and an Afghan government plan to abolish private security companies have muddled the plans and projects of private aid groups, officials say.
articles.abstract: Anti-American unrest and an Afghan government plan to abolish private security companies have muddled the plans and projects of private aid groups, officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The management at a company that does aid and development work for the American government knows that some of its employees in Afghanistan are keeping weapons in their rooms — and is choosing to look the other way. At another company in the same business, lawyers are examining whether the company can sue the United States Agency for International Development for material breach of contract, citing the deteriorating security in Afghanistan.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg and Graham Bowley

articles.headline: Got $100,000? Have a Cookie: Banks Try Luring the Top 10%
articles.snippet: Big banks are trying to sell higher-margin products like mutual funds, stocks and retirement advice to customers who have assets in the hundreds of thousands as a way to raise their revenue.
articles.abstract: Big banks are trying to sell higher-margin products like mutual funds, stocks and retirement advice to customers who have assets in the hundreds of thousands as a way to raise their revenue.
articles.lead_paragraph: LARCHMONT, N.Y. — Wine and cheese in the vault. After-hours appointments to suit busy schedules. And loads of marble and mahogany with not a teller in sight.

articles.headline: U.S. Sergeant Is Said to Kill 16 Civilians in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: Nine children were among the dead after an American soldier stalked from home to home in attacks in a rural stretch of southern Afghanistan, Afghan and American officials said.
articles.abstract: Nine children were among the dead after an American soldier stalked from home to home in attacks in a rural stretch of southern Afghanistan, Afghan and American officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: PANJWAI, Afghanistan — Stalking from home to home, a United States Army sergeant methodically killed at least 16 civilians, 9 of them children, in a rural stretch of southern Afghanistan early on Sunday, igniting fears of a new wave of anti-American hostility, Afghan and American officials said.
articles.byline: By Taimoor Shah and Graham Bowley

articles.headline: ‘Ishtar’ Lands on Mars
articles.snippet: “John Carter,” Disney’s big-budget epic, is a new example of the Hollywood studios’ habit of pouring more money into looming flops to stay on good terms with their stars.
articles.abstract: “John Carter,” Disney’s big-budget epic, is a new example of the Hollywood studios’ habit of pouring more money into looming flops to stay on good terms with their stars.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In 1987, shortly before the release of “Ishtar,” Columbia Pictures realized the film was going to flop in catastrophic fashion. But rather than cut advertising spending to minimize the financial damage — as the studio’s top marketer advised — Columbia did the opposite, pouring even more money into ads.

articles.headline: A Code of Conduct for Content Aggregators
articles.snippet: Two approaches to giving credit where credit belongs online were announced at the South by Southwest Interactive festival in Austin.
articles.abstract: Two approaches to giving credit where credit belongs online were announced at the South by Southwest Interactive festival in Austin.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex.

articles.headline: New Layer of Content Amid Chaos on YouTube
articles.snippet: Some YouTube channels that were announced in October are beginning to provide content, raising hopes that they can attract enough subscribers to raise advertising rates.
articles.abstract: Some YouTube channels that were announced in October are beginning to provide content, raising hopes that they can attract enough subscribers to raise advertising rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: For a glimpse at the next phase in YouTube’s evolution, look no further than a stray crutch and a $20 birthday cake for Justin Bieber.

articles.headline: Health Care Act Offers Roberts a Signature Case
articles.snippet: Considered likely to join the Supreme Court majority either way the case is decided, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. may never encounter a more important ruling.
articles.abstract: Considered likely to join the Supreme Court majority either way the case is decided, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. may never encounter a more important ruling.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. takes his usual center seat on the Supreme Court bench on March 26, he will begin presiding over an extraordinary three days of arguments that will determine the fate of President Obama’s sweeping health care law.

articles.headline: A Site That Aims to Unleash the Scrapbook Maker in All of Us
articles.snippet: Pinterest, the most talked about start-up of the spring, lets users curate photographs online, essentially making scrapbooks that link back to the original source of each image.
articles.abstract: Pinterest, the most talked about start-up of the spring, lets users curate photographs online, essentially making scrapbooks that link back to the original source of each image.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Seeking attention for your start-up? You may want to look beyond the Internet-savvy throngs clogging the sidewalks and bars here.

articles.headline: Latest Stress Tests Are Expected to Show Progress at Most Banks
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve this week will release the results of its latest stress tests, which are expected to show broadly improved balance sheets at most institutions.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve this week will release the results of its latest stress tests, which are expected to show broadly improved balance sheets at most institutions.
articles.lead_paragraph: In another milestone in the banking industry’s recovery from the financial crisis, the Federal Reserve this week will release the results of its latest stress tests, which are expected to show broadly improved balance sheets at most institutions.

articles.headline: Tight G.O.P. Primaries Suggest Less-Predictable South
articles.snippet: Volatile contests in Alabama and Mississippi, both of which hold primaries on Tuesday, suggest a fragmented and fickle Southern electorate.
articles.abstract: Volatile contests in Alabama and Mississippi, both of which hold primaries on Tuesday, suggest a fragmented and fickle Southern electorate.
articles.lead_paragraph: HUNTSVILLE, Ala. — They stood beneath a Saturn V rocket, baby-carrying mothers, cross-armed men, workers in coveralls and financial planners, listening as Rick Santorum told them who they were and why they mattered.

articles.headline: For Creators of Games, a Faint Line on Cloning
articles.snippet: Some small video game makers say the line between inspiration and shameless copying seems to have all but disappeared.
articles.abstract: Some small video game makers say the line between inspiration and shameless copying seems to have all but disappeared.
articles.lead_paragraph: In any commercialized art form, be it movies, literature or fashion, the creators often tread a fine line between inspiration and shameless copying. Some small video game makers say that line seems to have all but disappeared.

articles.headline: Keeper of Islamic Flame Rises as Egypt’s New Decisive Voice
articles.snippet: Khairat el-Shater, a leader of Egypt’s Muslim Brotherhood and an advocate for moderation and modernization, says that recent elections have proved that Egyptians want an explicitly Islamic state.
articles.abstract: Khairat el-Shater, a leader of Egypt’s Muslim Brotherhood and an advocate for moderation and modernization, says that recent elections have proved that Egyptians want an explicitly Islamic state.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — For more than a dozen years, Khairat el-Shater guided his family of 10 children, his sprawling business empire and Egypt’s largest Islamist movement, the Muslim Brotherhood, all from a prison cell.

articles.headline: An Afghan Comes Home to a Massacre
articles.snippet: Once a believer in the offensive against the Taliban, Abdul Samad, who lost 11 family members in a rampage, is now insistent that United States forces get out. Officials said the attack was carried out by an American sergeant.
articles.abstract: Once a believer in the offensive against the Taliban, Abdul Samad, who lost 11 family members in a rampage, is now insistent that United States forces get out. Officials said the attack was carried out by an American sergeant.
articles.lead_paragraph: PANJWAI, Afghanistan — Displaced by the war, Abdul Samad finally moved his large family back home to this volatile district of southern Afghanistan last year. He feared the Taliban, but his new house was nestled near an American military base, where he considered himself safe.
articles.byline: By Taimoor Shah and Graham Bowley

articles.headline: Pepsi Chief Shuffles Management to Soothe Investors
articles.snippet: The changes laid out a potential line of succession to Indra K. Nooyi and were aimed at addressing investor concerns over its stock price.
articles.abstract: The changes laid out a potential line of succession to Indra K. Nooyi and were aimed at addressing investor concerns over its stock price.
articles.lead_paragraph: Indra K. Nooyi’s vision of PepsiCo as a company that sells nutritional products — not just sodas and salty chips — has been hailed as a sound long-term strategy by management consultants and nutritionists almost since her arrival at the company nearly six years ago.
